newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran assembly re-elects conservative as speaker.
newsitem.headline: Iran assembly re-elects conservative as speaker.

text.p: The conservative Shi'ite Moslem clergyman defeated in Iran's presidential election was chosen again on Sunday as speaker of parliament, signalling president-elect Mohammad Khatami could face a tough time ahead.

Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri, the conservative clerical establishment's candidate for the presidency, was re-elected to his third one-year term as speaker of the 270-seat Majlis. Nateq-Nouri, the only candidate for speaker, was re-elected by 211 deputies compared with 146 last year.

A threatened challenge by the dominant conservatives' centrist opponents, who had spoken of nominating former interior minister Abdullah Nouri, failed to appear. He had secured 92 votes in a challenge last year.
In the May 23 presidential poll Nateq-Nouri won only 25 percent of the popular vote compared with Khatami's landslide 69 percent of 29 million votes cast.
Iranian analysts said Nateq-Nouri's re-election as speaker could be a problem for Khatami, a moderate cleric who must submit his cabinet to parliament for confirmation.
Iran News daily said the election would have a decisive impact on Khatami's cabinet. The political faction that won the speakership would dominate the cabinet, it said.
Khatami, who takes over from outgoing President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani in August, has not disclosed who is in the running for ministerial posts.
